assumptions.text: Classical mechanics framework: relativistic effects negligible (v << c), quantum effects negligible for macroscopic bodies

symbol_definitions.definition: de Broglie wavelength of particles in the system
Characteristic length scale of the system

assumptions.text: Both bodies can be treated as point masses with spherically symmetric mass distributions
Observations are made from an inertial (non-accelerating) reference frame
Conservation laws (energy, momentum, angular momentum) hold for the system

symbol_definitions.definition: Total momentum vector of the system
Total angular momentum vector of the system

assumptions.text: Two-body gravitational systems with negligible external perturbations
Gravitational field strength allows for Newtonian approximation
System is sufficiently isolated from external influences
The spectral energy density `u(nu,T)` describes radiation from a perfect black body - an idealized emitter that absorbs all incident radiation and re-emits it purely based on temperature `T`
The radiation field is in thermal equilibrium at temperature `T`, meaning the emission and absorption rates are balanced and the energy distribution is time-independent
The electromagnetic field is quantized into discrete energy levels for each mode

symbol_definitions.definition: Energy of the nth quantum state

assumptions.text: Electromagnetic waves have two independent polarization directions (transverse to propagation direction)
The speed of light in vacuum is constant and independent of the motion of the source or observer

symbol_definitions.definition: Speed of light in vacuum, exact value by definition in SI units.

assumptions.text: Reference frames move with constant relative velocity (no acceleration)
The system can be described by a finite number of generalized coordinates `q_i(t)` and their time derivatives `dot q_i(t)`
The Lagrangian `L(q_i, dot q_i, t)` is a well-defined function of the generalized coordinates, velocities, and possibly time
The Lagrangian is at least twice continuously differentiable with respect to all its arguments
The trajectory of the system in configuration space is smooth and differentiable throughout the time interval of interest
The initial and final configurations of the system are held fixed during variational analysis
Small, arbitrary variations of the system's trajectory are permitted in the interior of the time interval for variational analysis
The system obeys the principle of stationary action (least action principle), meaning the path taken by the system makes the action stationary, leading to the Euler-Lagrange equations
Spacetime is flat, no gravitational effects considered
Particles have well-defined rest masses
